You have any questions or concerns about your condition or care plan.

Spring 2024 booster: * Should be at least 6 months since the previous COVID-19 vaccine or known COVID-19 infection. * Interval may be shortened to 3 months to support implementation of the Spring vaccination campaign. * Patients are eligible if they are at increased risk of severe illness from COVID-19: * Adults 65 years of age and older, * Adult residents of long-term care homes and other congregate living settings for seniors, * Individuals 6 months of age and older who are moderately to severely immunocompromised (due to an underlying condition or treatment), or * Individuals 55 years and older who identify as First Nations, Inuit, or Metis and their non-Indigenous household members who are 55 years and older
Not previously vaccinated: * Recommended for all patients 5 years and older. * Recommended for all patients 6 months to 4 years old and at high risk of severe illness due to COVID-19. * May be offered to patients 6 months to 4 years old who are not at high risk of severe illness due to COVID-19.

Not previously vaccinated: * Recommended for all patients 9 years to less than 27 years of age. * May be considered for patients 27 years of age and older who are at ongoing risk of exposure to HPV. * An immunization series consists of 3 doses of HPV9 vaccine administered at months 0, 2, and 6. * A 2-dose schedule (adminstered at months 0 and 6) may be considered for immunocompetent adolescents 9 to less than 15 years of age.

* Vaccination should be recommended for all patients over the age of 6 months who does not have contraindications and has not already been immunized for the current influenza season. * Children 6 months to less than 9 years of age who have never received influenza vaccine in a previous influenza season should be given 2 doses of influenza vaccine (administered at least 4 weeks apart) in the current season.

Not previously vaccinated with the recombinant zoster vaccine (RZV): * Vaccination is recommended for individuals ≥50 years of age without contraindications. * Individuals ≥50 years of age without contraindications who received the live-attenuated zoster vaccine, or who have had a previous episode of herpes zoster, should be vaccinated with RZV after at least one year. * Vaccination may be considered for immunocompromised adults ≥50 years of age based on a case-by-case assessment of the benefits vs risks. * An immunization series consists of 2 doses of RZV administered 2 to 6 months apart.
consumes ≥1 pack of cigarettes (20) per day
Symptoms worsen at any point after therapy is initiated.
For example, if Rx was given, it was dispensed and taken as prescribed.

* For males, consuming ≥ 5 drinks per occasion, at least once a month during the past year, or > 14 drinks per week. * For females, consuming ≥ 4 drinks per occasion, at least once a month during the past year, or > 7 drinks per week. * 1 drink = 12 oz. beer with 5% alcohol, 5 oz. wine with 12% alcohol, or 1.5 oz hard liquor with 40% alcohol.

* For males, consuming <5 drinks per occasion, or ≤14 drinks per week. * For females, consuming <4 drinks per occasion, or ≤7 drinks per week. * 1 drink = 12 oz. beer with 5% alcohol, 5 oz. wine with 12% alcohol, or 1.5 oz hard liquor with 40% alcohol.
This indicates a poor or no response to therapy. Referral to primary care provider is warranted
Referral to primary care provider for further medical evaluation is necessary.
Advise patient to discontinue therapy, report any serious adverse effects to their health-care practitioner(s), and seek prompt medical evaluation.
Refer to primary care provider for further investigation.
Clinical presentation is not consistent with {{ailment, lowercase}} and referral for further investigation may be warranted.

Aerobic physical activity (e.g., brisk walking, cycling, jogging) for ≥ 150 minutes per week.

* Consider documenting the patient\'s current and previous approaches to caring for the ailment. * This may include indicating the approximate year of diagnosis, what the patient was instructed to do by primary care provider(s), or other pertinent information about the medical approach.

"* Consider documenting the patient\'s current and previous approaches to therapy for the ailment. * If any approach was tried, specify which one and whether it was (in)effective and/or (not)well-tolerated. "

Select time and date for the follow-up consultation.

* Pharmacists may choose to prescribe an alternative or additional agent if they deem it appropriate after a therapeutic assessment. * Refer to Schedule A of the BC Pharmacists Regulation: https://www.bclaws.gov.bc.ca/civix/document/id/complete/statreg/417_2008 * Refer to College of Pharmacists of British Columbia guidance documents: https://www.bcpharmacists.org/ppmac

* Pharmacists may choose to prescribe an alternative or additional agent if they deem it appropriate after a therapeutic assessment. * Refer to Schedule 4 of the Ontario regulations 202/94: https://www.ontario.ca/laws/regulation/r23179 * Refer to OCP\'s guidance documents: https://www.ocpinfo.com/practice-education/expanded-scope-of-practice/minor-ailment/
Pharmacists may choose to prescribe an alternative or additional agent if they deem it appropriate after a therapeutic assessment.

What therapies have been tried in the past for this ailment (including for this episode)?

* Any agent(s) listed here will export to the second prescription that generates which is for patient records only (not to be processed or billed through public or private drug plans). * A pharmacist may NOT prescribe a drug that falls outside of scope of practice (see the Alberta College of Pharmacy\'s Standards of Practice for Pharmacists and Pharmacy Technicians for more information). * These non-prescription and/or natural health products may be recommended instead. * The only exception is for patients with NIHB coverage, for which self-care products may be covered if recommended by a pharmacist.

* Any agent(s) listed here will export to the prescription that generates with the appropriate billing PIN associated with it.* A pharmacist may only prescribe a Schedule 1 drug or blood product in accordance with the [Standards of Practice](https://kings-printer.alberta.ca/1266.cfm?page=2023_022.cfm&leg_type=Regs&isbncln=9780779840748).
Include any other safety parameters provided as well as additional strategies for managing common adverse effects.

Only hypersensitivities that are pertinent to prescribing for {{ailment, lowercase}} are listed here.
Hypersensitivity includes allergic and/or non-allergic reactions.
Inquire about any new problems as well as atypical and red flag signs and symptoms that have emerged since initiation of therapy.

Inquire about whether any adverse effects to the prescribed therapy occurred.
Report any suspected side effects associated with the use of health products to Health Canada by: 1. Visiting the Web page on Adverse Reaction Reporting (https://www.canada.ca/en/health-canada/services/drugs-health-products/medeffect-canada/adverse-reaction-reporting.html); or 2. Calling toll-free at 1-866-234-2345.
A medical diagnosis is one that is provided by a primary care provider (i.e., physician, nurse practitioner) or a pharmacist.

* Any agent(s) listed here will export to the second prescription that generates which is for patient records only (not to be processed or billed through public or private drug plans). * A pharmacist may NOT prescribe a drug that falls outside of Schedule A of the BC Pharmacists Regulations and/or outside of Schedule I of the Drug Schedules Regulation * These non-prescription and/or natural health products may be recommended instead. * The only exception is for patients with PharmaCare Plan W, for which self-care products may be covered if recommended by a pharmacist.

* Any agent(s) listed here will export to the prescription that generates with the appropriate billing PIN associated with it. * A pharmacist may only prescribe a drug listed in of the Pharmacists Regulations under the Health Professions Act (https://www.bclaws.gov.bc.ca/civix/document/id/complete/statreg/417_2008). * Additionally, a pharmacist may only prescribe a drug listed in Schedule I of the Drug Schedules Regulation under the Pharmacy Operations and Drug Scheduling Act (https://www.bclaws.gov.bc.ca/civix/document/id/complete/statreg/9_98).
